name: US U-turn could see coronavirus vaccine patents set aside
introduction: To the surprise of many, the US government has backed a World Trade Organization (WTO) proposal to disclaim certain intellectual property (IP) rights to coronavirus vaccines, after previously opposing it.
content:
To the surprise of many, the US government has backed a World Trade Organization (WTO) proposal to disclaim certain intellectual property (IP) rights to coronavirus vaccines, after previously opposing it.

The temporary waiver could enable developing countries to manufacture COVID-19 vaccines which were developed by drugmakers such as Pfizer (NYSE: PFE) and Moderna (Nasdaq: MRNA), without falling foul of patent law.

US Trade Representative Katherine Tai said the Biden administration “believes strongly in intellectual property protections, but in service of ending this pandemic, supports the waiver of those protections for COVID-19 vaccines.”

Radical action

At a time when the novel coronavirus continues to spread widely in many countries, public health groups have been critical of the slow pace of vaccine rollouts, with richer countries tending to monopolize access.

With the threat from new variants of the virus ever present, there are also concerns that rising numbers of cases globally could provide the conditions for a vaccine-beating mutation to develop.

COVID-19 infections are still increasing in 42 countries, with a global total of over 150 million cases so far. India is currently reporting close to 400,000 new cases per day.

Anna Marriott, health policy manager at Oxfam, said that the current approach to vaccination had “so far denied access to these life-saving tools for billions of people.”

She added: “As thousands of people die daily in India, the continued failure of the G7 to break with the pharma-controlled monopolies is inexcusable.”

Industry reaction

Vaccine developers have been ramping up production, promising significant increases in supply in the coming months.

This includes Moderna, which recently announced plans to manufacture up to three billion doses of its mRNA-based product in 2022.

Despite this, the lack of availability in the short and medium term has prompted countries to support the IP waiver, proposed by India and South Africa, which would pave the way for unbranded versions of leading vaccines to be developed.

The pharmaceutical industry has criticized the move, however, questioning whether checks on quality and safety could guarantee the products.

The industry is also concerned that the waiver would remove incentives for companies to continue researching new variants, diagnostics and treatments, while making it less likely that the private sector would react quickly in the event of another pandemic.

Nathalie Moll, director general of European pharma trade group EFPIA called the decision “short-sighted” and “ineffectual,” adding it would put “the hard-won progress in fighting this terrible disease in jeopardy.”

She said: “While we wholeheartedly agree with the goal of protecting citizens around the world through vaccines, waiving patents will make winning the fight against the coronavirus even harder.”
